body:
Problem: When using nvim_buf_set_text to insert text before a visual 
selection, the "other end" of the selection stays at the same column 
while the cursor moves correctly.

Solution: Add VIsual position adjustment logic in fix_cursor_cols() to 
ensure both ends of visual selection move consistently when text is 
inserted.
Fix #29558

comment_regular_data.body:
I just re-encountered this issue (#29558), when collaboratively editing in [Ethersync](https://github.com/ethersync/ethersync).

@glepnir, what's the status of this PR? :)
Oh, this PR has been around for quite a while. I'll take a look at it in the next few days.
@blinry Hello  I’ve updated the PR. I used your reproduction steps to write a test case and it passes. Could you give this PR a try?

Thanks to getting back to this so quickly, @glepnir! I tried the PR – this solves the issue in many cases!

But I still found a case where the selection shifts around: When inserting or removing lines before the selection. Is it possible that the columns are shifted now, but the rows are not (yet)?

## To reproduce

Start with the buffer content

```
1
2
3
```

Run

```
:lua vim.defer_fn(function() vim.api.nvim_buf_set_text(0,0,0,0,0,{"0",""}) end, 3000)
```

to insert a line "0" at the front in 3 seconds. While the timeout is running, visually select the line "2" with `V`.

Result: Lines "1" and "2" are selected.
Expected result: Only line "2" is selected.
I have update. now should works. because before just modified the column logic in fix_cursor_cols. the new bug you mentioned need a smiliar logic for line in fix_cursor.

This is a big improvement! I found two more edge case related to insertions in the first line of the selection, maybe you have an idea? Maybe both have the same solution. (This is kind of fun, I hope it is for you, as well!)

# Case 1

Start with buffer content

```
1
2
```

Run this to insert a "0" in front of the "1":

```
:lua vim.defer_fn(function() vim.api.nvim_buf_set_text(0,0,0,0,0,{"0"}) end, 3000)
```

Select both lines while the timeout is running.

Result: The first line is selected
Expected result: Both lines are still selected

# Case 2

Start with buffer content

```
123
```

Run this to insert a newline in front of the "1":

```
:lua vim.defer_fn(function() vim.api.nvim_buf_set_text(0,0,0,0,0,{"", ""}) end, 3000)
```

Select the 2 visually while the timeout is running.

Result: The newline, as well as the 1 and 2 are selected
Expected result: The 2 is still selected
another case when using visual-block..still need adjust..and there also need a similar change in nvim_buf_set_lines.

I tested the current state of this branch:

- line-wise selection: works perfectly! :sparkles:
- block selection: as you said, seems to need adjustment of the "other end"
- regular selection: if text is inserted in the same line but *after* the column of the "other end", its position is (falsely) shifted to the right

## To reproduce

Start with `123`, visually select the 2, then insert a 4 at the end of the line.

Expected result: 2 is still selected
Actual result: 23 is selected

Here are the edge cases that need to be handled. What confuses me is whether the visual start or end should follow the selected cell or remain fixed at the mark (row, col). If it's fixed, when the row/col changes (e.g., the original line is replaced with an empty line), the visual start or end column may no longer be valid. The case with Visual-block is different because it always maintains a rectangle. There are many edge cases to consider here. Vim only has setline for full line replacement. When the visual start becomes invalid, Vim exits Visual mode. Alternatively, a simpler approach could be to prevent text insertion while Visual mode is active, keeping it in sync. @justinmk  any idea...

- Preventing buffer modifications when Visual mode is active would break our use-case of collaborative text editing, so I would not go in that direction.
- For block-wise selections, it's indeed not entirely clear what the "expected" behavior should be. But to me, it feels like the block is spanned by the cursor and the "other end", and both should be pushed around in the same way by edits. That would feel consistent with the way I'd expect regular selections to behave.
- When setting a line that contained the cursor or "other end" to be empty, my favorite solution would be to let the position "fall back" to the first column. That's what's currently happening to the cursor position under edits already.

Do you have an idea for what needs to be done to not shift the "other end" in case of an insertion after its column, in the case of a regular selection? That's the last "To reproduce" case I described in my last comment. I think if we could fix that, this would be a big improvement to the status quo! We could tackle `nvim_buf_set_lines` in a follow-up PR.

> Do you have an idea for what needs to be done to not shift the "other end" in case of an insertion after its column, in the case of a regular selection? 

Adding some start and end col checks in the current PR should be able to handle it. But this will add some extra code... Maybe not what Justin wants because he wants to keep it simple. I am currently just confused about how to adjust the mark in different visual modes. Visual and Visual block cannot be processed synchronously. the visual-block mode is skipped in the current PR...
